summary: Is it just me or in the show s1 they show Arya bullying Sansa way more than vice versa? I am a fan of both of them but have...
question: Is it just me or in the show s1 they show Arya bullying Sansa way more than vice versa? I am a fan of both of them but have noticed they both can get heavily mischaracterized in the show
answer:
I am going to assume you mean the food throwing scene in the first episode. In which, sort of. But real problem is that they changed the actual dynamic of Arya and her role and relationships in the stark family. You can see that in the bow scene as well, with arya shooting the bow and everybody laughing and kind of being supportive? In the books, Catelyn would have been furious and would have dragged her right back to Septa Mordane, and Ned wouldnt be approving at all (despite how much he loves Arya, he is still a traditional man with a traditional mindset and a young noble girl with a bow without permission is a big no no.) This is actually very important because the whole concept is that despite how wild Arya is, it’s not approved by anyone and she is expected to behave in a certain way  and it plays a very important part in her characterisation (her self-consciousness, her feeling of being an outcast, her need to belong, her lack of self-confidence and self-worth). The same thing happens in the food scene. Arya throws food at her old sister, in a feast filled with the noble men and the royal family, during a royal visit and seconds after her sister just spoke with queen, is so unrealistic. It’s supposed to be this sweet family moment where we see Arya being mischievous, and show how everyone finds it funny, but in the books, Arya first wouldnt dare (girl might not be one for rules but she at least tries to behave herself, especially when she knows her butt is going to be handed to her if she doesnt). And Arya really isnt that kind of person. She is more play in the mud despite being told not to, and sneak to the older kid’s kind of mischievous. And if she is rude, its probably warranted. In that scene, Sansa and Arya werent even interacting and the food throwing was completely unwarranted. I mean, its not even a big deal, but it can be seen as “bullying” and generally something mean, and makes Sansa seem more of an outcast and a target than Arya (which is NOT the case). And they also cut out the part Sansa played in their relationship (horseface, “ugly as hodor”, “they should have killed you instead of Lady”) in order to make Sansa more likable. So in response to your question, kind of but its more complicated (?) than that. 

I actually saw a post (i think it was by gendrie or someone else) that explained this quite well. At least, in more comprehensive way than me. If i find it, i will send it your way.

summary: Wrote a big Arya and Sansa conversation for a fanfic and remembered how salty I am that D&D decided to pit them against each...
body: Wrote a big Arya and Sansa conversation for a fanfic and remembered how salty I am that D&D decided to pit them against each other for cheap drama after all they’ve been through. And yeah, even if you choose to read it as “they were pretending the whole time” we know that’s not what D&D intended cause of that stupid deleted scene. Anyway, Arya and Sansa better be ride-or-die in the last season.

by poutingsliver

Welcome to Love Island!

11 lovely singles are about to battle it out in the game of love. Will they find what they’re looking for? Or will they leave just as single? Will they make it to the end? Or be booted too soon? Find out on Love Island Westeros! From the North to Meereen meet our 11 singles and decide who you’re rooting for, get ready it’s about to be wild.

(The Love Island AU that no one asked for)

blog.title: Princess Arya the Valiant
blog.description: A devoted fan defending her precious cinnamon roll, its all you need to know!...and i love cheesecake...bye. Currently on hiatus.

summary: Arya most likely wouldn’t have survived in Sansa’s place. Sansa most likely wouldn’t have survived in Arya’s place. They are...
question: Arya most likely wouldn’t have survived in Sansa’s place. Sansa most likely wouldn’t have survived in Arya’s place. They are immediately painted as polar opposite characters to each other that have little in common yet people still compare them?? And expect one to behave like the other?? Like ??? How??? They’re so different!
answer: I wouldn’t say that they wont be able to. Despite their differences, one thing that Arya and Sansa have in common is that they are survivors. They are adaptable, they are capable of changing themselves in amazing ways to accommodate themselves in different situations. They do have different skill sets in some aspects that are best utilised in the canon plots, but there is nothing to say they wont have been able to survive (make it through in the end alive) if their situations had been exchanged. Yes, initially they would have struggled. Arya is more familiar with  commoners and had an easier time in adjusting to the environmental ( & social?) change than Sansa would have. And Arya is not as good with her words as Sansa is. But the whole idea is that the struggles and journeys both characters go through are learning experiences (horrifically traumatic ones) as well, and both sisters are quick learners and despite struggles, i definitely believe both would have made it through in the end.

blog.description: 23/grad student/book nerd/ lover of arya stark/ Meera Reed defender/ searching for Edric Dayne/ mainly Jonrya and Gendrya

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary: I know we all sit here an say Matrin is cruel to x y z character, but I would like to argue that Martin at his cruelest would...
body:
I know we all sit here an say Matrin is cruel to x y z character, but I would like to argue that Martin at his cruelest would be what happened to Jeyne Poole. It is simultaneously the most ironic and saddest situation in the series for me. 

In the beginning of this series Jeyne is Sansa’s best friend 

“If only she had someone to tell her what to do. She missed Septa Mordane, and even more Jeyne Poole, her truest friend.” - Sansa II, ACoK 

“Joffrey likes your sister,“ Jeyne whispered, proud as if she had something to do with it. She was the daughter of Winterfell’s steward and Sansa’s dearest friend. "He told her she was very beautiful.” - Arya I, GoT

And Arya’s childhood bully 

“Arya took after their lord father. Her hair was a lusterless brown, and her face was long and solemn. Jeyne used to call her Arya Horseface, and neigh whenever she came near. It hurt that the one thing Arya could do better than her sister was ride a horse.” - Arya I, GoT

“They’d been her friends, she’d felt safe around them, but now she knew that was a lie. They’d let the queen kill Lady, that was horrible enough, but then the Hound found Mycah. Jeyne Poole had told Arya that he’d cut him up in so many pieces that they’d given him back to the butcher in a bag, and at first the poor man had thought it was a pig they’d slaughtered. And no one had raised a voice or drawn a blade or anything, not Harwin who always talked so bold, or Alyn who was going to be a knight, or Jory who was captain of the guard. Not even her father.” - Arya II, GoT

It is with Arya that the irony kicks in. Jeyne Poole seems to look down on Arya and i think envies her place a little. Arya Horseface, who is scrawny and plain and cannot do anything but sums right, is one day going to be a Lady and rule a castle. As we know it is not really realistic for Jeyne Poole to get herself a Lord. 

“I suppose,” Sansa said doubtfully. Beric Dondarrion was handsome enough, but he was awfully old, almost twenty-two; the Knight of Flowers would have been much better. Of course, Jeyne had been in love with Lord Beric ever since she had first glimpsed him in the lists. Sansa thought she was being silly; Jeyne was only a steward’s daughter, after all, and no matter how much she mooned after him, Lord Beric would never look at someone so far beneath him, even if she hadn’t been half his age.” - Sansa II, GoT

A knight like Beric Donderrion would look at Arya, though. She might be plain and what not, but she has some old blood running through those veins. I dont think it is out of the realm of possibility that Jeyne (who is somewhere between 11 and 13)  would feel this was not fair. 

Then everything falls apart. House Stark is purged, her father is dead, and she is presumably being trained by Petyr Baelish (which is just got turning)

“I’m a good girl,“ Jeyne whimpered. ”They trained me.“ - Theon I, ADwD 
(There is an implication there and it is 100% not good and not okay)

And Jeyne gets what she (might) have wanted in the worst possible way. She is married to a Great Lord (Ramsay Bolton), she is considered Sansa’s true sister, she has her own castle, and a pinch of hope. 

“The bride raised her eyes. Brown eyes, shining in the candlelight. "I will be a good wife to him, and t-true. I … I will please him and give him sons. I will be a better wife than the real Arya could have been, he’ll see.”
 - Prince of Winterfell

And it is a complete nightmare. 

Jeyne is now Arya Stark and as such she is sexually, physically, and mentally abused. She has what she wanted in the worst way possible and it is so freaking sad. I get why Martin used Jeyne Poole, but i wonder if he had to be so brutal. Maybe it was to snap Theon into running, but honestly it is rough. 

Jeyne Poole was the Stewards girl, Sansa Stark’s best friend, Arya Stark’s childhood bully, the Lady of Winterfell, and she deserved so much better than she got. By the end of all of this someone better give her a happy ending.

reblog.comment:

“Joffrey likes your sister,“ Jeyne whispered, proud as if she had something to do with it. She was the daughter of Winterfell’s steward and Sansa’s dearest friend. "He told her she was very beautiful.” - Arya I, GoT

And Arya’s childhood bully 

“Arya took after their lord father. Her hair was a lusterless brown, and her face was long and solemn. Jeyne used to call her Arya Horseface, and neigh whenever she came near. It hurt that the one thing Arya could do better than her sister was ride a horse.” - Arya I, GoT

“They’d been her friends, she’d felt safe around them, but now she knew that was a lie. They’d let the queen kill Lady, that was horrible enough, but then the Hound found Mycah. Jeyne Poole had told Arya that he’d cut him up in so many pieces that they’d given him back to the butcher in a bag, and at first the poor man had thought it was a pig they’d slaughtered. And no one had raised a voice or drawn a blade or anything, not Harwin who always talked so bold, or Alyn who was going to be a knight, or Jory who was captain of the guard. Not even her father.” - Arya II, GoT

It is with Arya that the irony kicks in. Jeyne Poole seems to look down on Arya and i think envies her place a little. Arya Horseface, who is scrawny and plain and cannot do anything but sums right, is one day going to be a Lady and rule a castle. As we know it is not really realistic for Jeyne Poole to get herself a Lord. 

“I suppose,” Sansa said doubtfully. Beric Dondarrion was handsome enough, but he was awfully old, almost twenty-two; the Knight of Flowers would have been much better. Of course, Jeyne had been in love with Lord Beric ever since she had first glimpsed him in the lists. Sansa thought she was being silly; Jeyne was only a steward’s daughter, after all, and no matter how much she mooned after him, Lord Beric would never look at someone so far beneath him, even if she hadn’t been half his age.” - Sansa II, GoT

A knight like Beric Donderrion would look at Arya, though. She might be plain and what not, but she has some old blood running through those veins. I dont think it is out of the realm of possibility that Jeyne (who is somewhere between 11 and 13)  would feel this was not fair. 

Then everything falls apart. House Stark is purged, her father is dead, and she is presumably being trained by Petyr Baelish (which is just got turning)

“I’m a good girl,“ Jeyne whimpered. ”They trained me.“ - Theon I, ADwD 
(There is an implication there and it is 100% not good and not okay)

And Jeyne gets what she (might) have wanted in the worst possible way. She is married to a Great Lord (Ramsay Bolton), she is considered Sansa’s true sister, she has her own castle, and a pinch of hope. 

“The bride raised her eyes. Brown eyes, shining in the candlelight. "I will be a good wife to him, and t-true. I … I will please him and give him sons. I will be a better wife than the real Arya could have been, he’ll see.”
 - Prince of Winterfell

And it is a complete nightmare. 

Jeyne is now Arya Stark and as such she is sexually, physically, and mentally abused. She has what she wanted in the worst way possible and it is so freaking sad. I get why Martin used Jeyne Poole, but i wonder if he had to be so brutal. Maybe it was to snap Theon into running, but honestly it is rough. 

Jeyne Poole was the Stewards girl, Sansa Stark’s best friend, Arya Stark’s childhood bully, the Lady of Winterfell, and she deserved so much better than she got. By the end of all of this someone better give her a happy ending.

trail.content_raw:
I know we all sit here an say Matrin is cruel to x y z character, but I would like to argue that Martin at his cruelest would be what happened to Jeyne Poole. It is simultaneously the most ironic and saddest situation in the series for me. 

In the beginning of this series Jeyne is Sansa’s best friend 

“If only she had someone to tell her what to do. She missed Septa Mordane, and even more Jeyne Poole, her truest friend.” - Sansa II, ACoK 

“Joffrey likes your sister,“ Jeyne whispered, proud as if she had something to do with it. She was the daughter of Winterfell’s steward and Sansa’s dearest friend. "He told her she was very beautiful.” - Arya I, GoT

Jeyne Poole had told Arya that he’d cut him up in so many pieces that they’d given him back to the butcher in a bag, and at first the poor man had thought it was a pig they’d slaughtered. And no one had raised a voice or drawn a blade or anything, not Harwin who always talked so bold, or Alyn who was going to be a knight, or Jory who was captain of the guard. Sansa thought she was being silly; Jeyne was only a steward’s daughter, after all, and no matter how much she mooned after him, Lord Beric would never look at someone so far beneath him, even if she hadn’t been half his age.” - Sansa II, GoT

“The bride raised her eyes. Brown eyes, shining in the candlelight. "I will be a good wife to him, and t-true. I … I will please him and give him sons. I will be a better wife than the real Arya could have been, he’ll see.”
 - Prince of Winterfell

And it is a complete nightmare. 

Jeyne is now Arya Stark and as such she is sexually, physically, and mentally abused. She has what she wanted in the worst way possible and it is so freaking sad. I get why Martin used Jeyne Poole, but i wonder if he had to be so brutal. Maybe it was to snap Theon into running, but honestly it is rough. 

Jeyne Poole was the Stewards girl, Sansa Stark’s best friend, Arya Stark’s childhood bully, the Lady of Winterfell, and she deserved so much better than she got. By the end of all of this someone better give her a happy ending.

summary:
But the pack survive?
I love how Jon and Arya looked like Northern and like their father in season 7 .
And How Sansa looked like...
body:
But the pack survive?

I love how Jon and Arya looked like Northern and like their father in season 7 .

And How Sansa looked like Cersei.


In book only Jon and Arya are like Northern look. They are like their father

Jon and Arya are like their direwolfs. Last two between siblings. ( Bran is actually three eyed raven. )

summary: Among all my frolicking in sunny California, I luckily also had time to upload the latest chapter of my time-travel fic, “This...
caption:
Among all my frolicking in sunny California, I luckily also had time to upload the latest chapter of my time-travel fic, “This Time We’ll Do Better”. Arya and Gendry and Nymeria, a happy pack travelling together - or are they??? 

“It won’t be like that,” Arya started, but then stopped. It would be like that. She would be scooped inside the family chambers to learn about sewing and singing and all the other stupid things young maids were supposed to learn, while Gendry would spend his time in the smithy, working alongside Mikken, if things went her way.

“You’ll get to eat in the big hall and we would still see each other. Sometime you might even be sitting next to my father in the high table; he likes to get to know people who serve under him,” she tried to soften the reality.

Thank you @hardlyfatal for betaing the new chapter, “The Pact”!

summary: Text exchange between my sister and I. My niece is 5 and we getting upset because my sister didn't understand she was saying...
body: Text exchange between my sister and I. My niece is 5 and we getting upset because my sister didn’t understand she was saying nocturnal. My sister should have known not to name her after Arya Stark and our aunt, who was also a spitfire.

blog.name: tatticstudio55
blog.title: pro jonerys who likes healthy debates

title: “Good boots are hard to find”
body:
November 20 – day 3 (foreshadowing and parallels)

The day before she goes blind, Arya slices the throat of a Night’s Watch deserter in Braavos, throw his body in the water and keep his boots.

That’s both echoing what happened to her mother at the Twins (her throat was sliced and her body dumped in the river) and what Jon does to Janos Slynt in ADWD: Slynt lose his head for refusing an order and Jon allows Owen the Oaf to help himself to Slynt’s boots. Arya kills Dareon for disobeying her brother’s orders, but we’re also told that Cat of the Canals used to walk around the Ragman’s Harbor “in a pair of battered boots too big for her feet” (Cat of the Canals – AFFC).

In her first ADWD chapter, Daenerys is offered a pair of slippers that are too small for her:

“Cleon the Great sends these slippers as a token of his love for Daenerys Stormborn, the Mother of Dragons.”

Irri slid the slippers onto Dany’s feet. They were gilded leather, decorated with green freshwater pearls. Does the butcher king believe a pair of pretty slippers will win my hand? “King Cleon is most generous. You may thank him for his lovely gift.” Lovely, but made for a child. Dany had small feet, yet the pointed slippers mashed her toes together. – Dany, ADWD

So… parallels? We’ll dig a bit further:

At the end of the day she would often sit on a rock and dangle her feet in the cool water. She had finally thrown away her cracked and rotted shoes. Walking barefoot was hard at first, but the blisters had finally broken, the cuts had healed, and her soles had turned to leather. The mud was nice between her toes, and she liked to feel the earth underfoot when she walked. – Arya, ACOK

 

The rocks had scraped her hands raw. They are better than they were, though, she decided as she picked at a broken blister. Her skin was pink and tender, and a pale milky fluid was leaking from her cracked palms, but her burns were healing.

The sun was hot this morning, the sky blue and cloudless. That was good. Dany’s clothes were hardly more than rags, and offered little in the way of warmth. One of her sandals had slipped off during her wild flight from Meereen and she had left the other up by Drogon’s cave, preferring to go barefoot rather than half-shod. – Daenerys, ADWD

Both girls are lost in nature, with broken blisters and healing injuries (cuts and burns) and both decide to go barefoot, Arya because her shoes were “cracked and rotted”, Dany for having lost one. However, whereas Arya’s soles “had turned to leather”, Dany’s feet blisters again:

She was very tired, and fresh blisters had appeared on both her feet, including a matched set upon her pinky toes. – Daenerys, ADWD

I tend to think that Arya’s feet were “hardened” by the fact that she was walking North, while Dany’s feet bled from her attempt at returning to Meereen.

The new skin beneath the blisters is a symbol of rebirth: Arya and Dany have “thrown away” and “scraped” their old skins, either because it was too old and “rotted” (in Arya’s case), or because it didn’t fit right (in Dany’s case). Arya’s feet successfully take roots, while Dany’s new path rejects her. Their bare feet might also have something to do with a reconnection with their spirit animals (and Dany loose one of her sandals in mid-air, which is also symbolic).

Cat’s boots are too big (probably pointing to how “lost” Arya feels in AFFC) and Dany’s slippers are too small (probably pointing to how “trapped” Dany feels in ADWD). Cat remains Cat through most of the chapter, until she kills Dareon and admit to the kindly man that it was “Arya of House Stark” who did it – perhaps because the act reconnects her with her mother and her brother Jon, and gets her a pair of boots that fit right.

Jon is another matter altogether: after killing Slynt, he gives the boots to someone else.

Janos Slynt twisted his neck around to stare up at him. “Please, my lord. Mercy. I’ll … I’ll go, I will, I …”

No, thought Jon. You closed that door. Longclaw descended. “Can I have his boots?” asked Owen the Oaf, as Janos Slynt’s head went rolling across the muddy ground. “They’re almost new, those boots. Lined with fur.”

Jon glanced back at Stannis. For an instant their eyes met. Then the king nodded and went back inside his tower. – Jon, ADWD

Side note: the “Tales of Peter Rabbit” by Beatrix Potter was translated in French under the title “le conte de Jeannot Lapin”. Isn’t it funny that Jon took Janos’s head, and Dany her “rabbit ears”, in the same book? But I digress. We know that Janos lost to Jon in the LC elections, and we know that Janos’s plans for the Night’s Watch, should he have been elected, were nowhere near Jon’s. Jon, obviously, has no interesting in wearing Janos’s boots. Owen the Oaf takes the boots and Jon takes the head.

The irony is that, had Jon worn Janos’s “boots”, he probably wouldn’t have been killed. But then, he wouldn’t be Jon. The boots likely wouldn’t fit him.

In any case, in asoiaf, the shoes you wear and don’t wear might reveal some things about who you are – and who you’re not.

No, thought Jon. You closed that door. Longclaw descended. “Can I have his boots?” asked Owen the Oaf, as Janos Slynt’s head went rolling across the muddy ground. “They’re almost new, those boots. Lined with fur.”

Jon glanced back at Stannis. For an instant their eyes met. Then the king nodded and went back inside his tower. – Jon, ADWD

Side note: the “Tales of Peter Rabbit” by Beatrix Potter was translated in French under the title “le conte de Jeannot Lapin”. Isn’t it funny that Jon took Janos’s head, and Dany her “rabbit ears”, in the same book? But I digress. We know that Janos lost to Jon in the LC elections, and we know that Janos’s plans for the Night’s Watch, should he have been elected, were nowhere near Jon’s. Jon, obviously, has no interesting in wearing Janos’s boots. Owen the Oaf takes the boots and Jon takes the head.

The irony is that, had Jon worn Janos’s “boots”, he probably wouldn’t have been killed. But then, he wouldn’t be Jon. The boots likely wouldn’t fit him.

In any case, in asoiaf, the shoes you wear and don’t wear might reveal some things about who you are – and who you’re not.

trail.content_raw:
November 20 – day 3 (foreshadowing and parallels)

The day before she goes blind, Arya slices the throat of a Night’s Watch deserter in Braavos, throw his body in the water and keep his boots.

That’s both echoing what happened to her mother at the Twins (her throat was sliced and her body dumped in the river) and what Jon does to Janos Slynt in ADWD: Slynt lose his head for refusing an order and Jon allows Owen the Oaf to help himself to Slynt’s boots. Arya kills Dareon for disobeying her brother’s orders, but we’re also told that Cat of the Canals used to walk around the Ragman’s Harbor “in a pair of battered boots too big for her feet” (Cat of the Canals – AFFC).

In her first ADWD chapter, Daenerys is offered a pair of slippers that are too small for her:

“Cleon the Great sends these slippers as a token of his love for Daenerys Stormborn, the Mother of Dragons.”

Irri slid the slippers onto Dany’s feet. They were gilded leather, decorated with green freshwater pearls. Does the butcher king believe a pair of pretty slippers will win my hand? “King Cleon is most generous. You may thank him for his lovely gift.” Lovely, but made for a child. Dany had small feet, yet the pointed slippers mashed her toes together. – Dany, ADWD

So… parallels? We’ll dig a bit further:

At the end of the day she would often sit on a rock and dangle her feet in the cool water. She had finally thrown away her cracked and rotted shoes. Walking barefoot was hard at first, but the blisters had finally broken, the cuts had healed, and her soles had turned to leather. The mud was nice between her toes, and she liked to feel the earth underfoot when she walked. – Arya, ACOK

 

The rocks had scraped her hands raw. They are better than they were, though, she decided as she picked at a broken blister. Her skin was pink and tender, and a pale milky fluid was leaking from her cracked palms, but her burns were healing.

The sun was hot this morning, the sky blue and cloudless. That was good. Dany’s clothes were hardly more than rags, and offered little in the way of warmth. One of her sandals had slipped off during her wild flight from Meereen and she had left the other up by Drogon’s cave, preferring to go barefoot rather than half-shod. – Daenerys, ADWD

Both girls are lost in nature, with broken blisters and healing injuries (cuts and burns) and both decide to go barefoot, Arya because her shoes were “cracked and rotted”, Dany for having lost one. However, whereas Arya’s soles “had turned to leather”, Dany’s feet blisters again:

She was very tired, and fresh blisters had appeared on both her feet, including a matched set upon her pinky toes. – Daenerys, ADWD

I tend to think that Arya’s feet were “hardened” by the fact that she was walking North, while Dany’s feet bled from her attempt at returning to Meereen.

The new skin beneath the blisters is a symbol of rebirth: Arya and Dany have “thrown away” and “scraped” their old skins, either because it was too old and “rotted” (in Arya’s case), or because it didn’t fit right (in Dany’s case). Arya’s feet successfully take roots, while Dany’s new path rejects her. Their bare feet might also have something to do with a reconnection with their spirit animals (and Dany loose one of her sandals in mid-air, which is also symbolic).

Cat’s boots are too big (probably pointing to how “lost” Arya feels in AFFC) and Dany’s slippers are too small (probably pointing to how “trapped” Dany feels in ADWD). Cat remains Cat through most of the chapter, until she kills Dareon and admit to the kindly man that it was “Arya of House Stark” who did it – perhaps because the act reconnects her with her mother and her brother Jon, and gets her a pair of boots that fit right.

Jon is another matter altogether: after killing Slynt, he gives the boots to someone else.

Janos Slynt twisted his neck around to stare up at him. “Please, my lord. Mercy. I’ll … I’ll go, I will, I …”

No, thought Jon. You closed that door. Longclaw descended. “Can I have his boots?” asked Owen the Oaf, as Janos Slynt’s head went rolling across the muddy ground. “They’re almost new, those boots. Lined with fur.”

Jon glanced back at Stannis. For an instant their eyes met. Then the king nodded and went back inside his tower. – Jon, ADWD

Side note: the “Tales of Peter Rabbit” by Beatrix Potter was translated in French under the title “le conte de Jeannot Lapin”. Isn’t it funny that Jon took Janos’s head, and Dany her “rabbit ears”, in the same book? But I digress. We know that Janos lost to Jon in the LC elections, and we know that Janos’s plans for the Night’s Watch, should he have been elected, were nowhere near Jon’s. Jon, obviously, has no interesting in wearing Janos’s boots. Owen the Oaf takes the boots and Jon takes the head.

The irony is that, had Jon worn Janos’s “boots”, he probably wouldn’t have been killed. But then, he wouldn’t be Jon. The boots likely wouldn’t fit him.

In any case, in asoiaf, the shoes you wear and don’t wear might reveal some things about who you are – and who you’re not.

Does the butcher king believe a pair of pretty slippers will win my hand? “King Cleon is most generous. You may thank him for his lovely gift.” Lovely, but made for a child. The sun was hot this morning, the sky blue and cloudless. That was good. Dany’s clothes were hardly more than rags, and offered little in the way of warmth. Janos Slynt twisted his neck around to stare up at him. “Please, my lord. Mercy. I’ll … I’ll go, I will, I …”

No, thought Jon. You closed that door. Longclaw descended. “Can I have his boots?” asked Owen the Oaf, as Janos Slynt’s head went rolling across the muddy ground. “They’re almost new, those boots. Lined with fur.”

Jon glanced back at Stannis. For an instant their eyes met. Then the king nodded and went back inside his tower. – Jon, ADWD
